code:
var emojibook=[{image:'/images/emoji/',id:1,gallery_id:1,emoji:"😀",name:"Grinning Face",meaning:"A yellow face with simple, open eyes and a broad, open smile, showing upper teeth and tongue on some platforms.
 Often conveys general pleasure and good cheer or humor.
 Not to be confused with 😃 Grinning Face With Big Eyes or 😄 Grinning Face With Smiling Eyes, which have the same smiles but more expressive eye shapes. 

 This emoji has a cat variant, 😺 Grinning Cat Face."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:2,gallery_id:1,emoji:"😃",name:"Grinning Face with Big ",meaning:"A yellow face with smiling eyes and a broad, open smile, showing upper teeth and tongue on some platforms. Often conveys general happiness and good-natured amusement.

 Similar to 😀 Grinning Face but with taller, more excited eyes. "},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:3,gallery_id:1,emoji:"😄",name:"Grinning Face with Smiling ",meaning:"A yellow face with smiling eyes and a broad, open smile, showing upper teeth and tongue on some platforms. Often conveys general happiness and good-natured amusement.

Similar to 😀 Grinning Face and 😃 Grinning Face With Big Eyes, but with warmer, less excited eyes.

This emoji has a cat variant, 😸 Grinning Cat Face With Smiling Eyes."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:4,gallery_id:1,emoji:"😁",name:"Beaming Face with Smiling ",meaning:"A yellow face with smiling eyes and full-toothed grin, as if saying Cheese! for the camera. Teeth may be smoothed-over or crosshatched. Often expresses a radiant, gratified happiness. Tone varies, including warm, silly, amused, or proud. 

Prior to 2017, Apple's design resembled its 😬 Grimacing Face."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:5,gallery_id:1,emoji:"😆",name:"Grinning Squinting Face",meaning:"A yellow face with a broad, open smile and scrunched, X-shaped eyes. Often conveys excitement or hearty laughter.
 Similar to 😀 Grinning Face but with eyes that might say Squee! or Awesome! An emoji form of the >< or xD emoticons. 

Grinning Squinting Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Smiling Face with Open Mouth and Tightly-Closed Eyes” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:6,gallery_id:1,emoji:"😅",name:"Grinning Face with Sweat",meaning:"Has the same grin and eyes as 😄 Grinning Face With Smiling Eyes but with a single, blue bead of sweat, usually over its left eye. Intended to depict nerves or discomfort but commonly used to express a close call, as if saying Whew! and wiping sweat from the forehead. 


Grinning Face with Sweat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Smiling Face with Open Mouth and Cold Sweat” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:7,gallery_id:1,emoji:"🤣",name:"Rolling on the Floor Laughing",meaning:"A yellow face with a big grin and scrunched, X-shaped eyes, tilted on its side as if rolling on the floor laughing (the internet acronym ROFL). Sheds two tears and tilts right on most platforms. Often conveys hysterical laughter more intense than 😂 Face With Tears of Joy.
 Microsoft's design previously featured a smiley with hands and feet. 

 Rolling on the Floor Laughing was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:8,gallery_id:1,emoji:"😂",name:"Face with Tears of Joy",meaning:"A yellow face with a big grin, uplifted eyebrows, and smiling eyes, each shedding a tear from laughing so hard. Widely used to show something is funny or pleasing. Named the Oxford Dictionaries 2015 Word of the Year, and the most used emoji on all platforms from 2011-2021.

 See also: 🤣 Rolling on the Floor Laughing which expresses more intense laughter; or cat variant: 😹 Cat Face With Tears of Joy.


 Face with Tears of Joy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:9,gallery_id:1,emoji:"🙂",name:"Slightly Smiling Face",meaning:"A yellow face with simple, open eyes and a thin, closed smile. Conveys a wide range of positive, happy, and friendly sentiments. Its tone can also be patronizing, passive-aggressive, or ironic, as if saying This is fine when it’s really not. 


 Slightly Smiling Face was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:11,gallery_id:2,emoji:"🙈",name:"See-No-Evil Monkey",meaning:"The see no evil monkey, called Mizaru (Japanese for “see not”), one of the Three Wise Monkeys. Depicted as the brown 🐵 Monkey Face with hands covering its eyes.
 The Three Wise Monkeys represent the proverb see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil, frequently interpreted as a call for discretion or willful ignorance.
 Often used as a playful way to convey a laughing, disbelieving, cringing I can’t believe what I’m seeing! or I can’t bear to look! 
 See also 🙉 Hear-No-Evil Monkey and 🙊 Speak-No-Evil Monkey.

This emoji is considered racist in some contexts, especially when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people.


 See-No-Evil Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:12,gallery_id:2,emoji:"🙉",name:"Hear-No-Evil Monkey",meaning:"The hear no evil monkey, called Kikazaru (Japanese for “hear not”), one of the Three Wise Monkeys. Depicted as the brown 🐵 Monkey Face with hands covering its ears.
 The Three Wise Monkeys represent the proverb see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil, frequently interpreted as a call for discretion or willful ignorance. 
 Often used as a playful way to convey I can’t believe what I’m hearing! or, more generally, to express astonishment or disbelief. 

 See also 🙈 See-No-Evil Monkey and 🙊 Speak-No-Evil Monkey.
  This emoji is considered racist in some contexts, especially when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people.


 Hear-No-Evil Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:13,gallery_id:2,emoji:"🙊",name:"Speak-No-Evil Monkey",meaning:"The speak no evil monkey, called Iwazaru (Japanese for “say not”), one of the Three Wise Monkeys. Depicted as the brown 🐵 Monkey Face with hands covering its mouth. 
 The Three Wise Monkeys represent the proverb see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil, frequently interpreted as a call for discretion or willful ignorance.
 Often used as a playful way to convey I can’t believe what I just said!, express a mischievous Oops!, or communicate a secret-keeping I won’t say a word. May be used to similar effect as 🤭 Face With Hand Over Mouth or 🤐 Zipper Mouth.
 See also 🙈 See-No-Evil Monkey and 🙉 Hear-No-Evil Monkey.

This emoji is considered racist in some contexts, especially when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people.


 Speak-No-Evil Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:14,gallery_id:2,emoji:"💥",name:"Collision",meaning:"A cartoon-styled representation of a collision. Depicted as a star-like, orange-and-yellow fiery burst, generally with one point extending to the bottom right, as if from the source of the collision.
May be used to represent various types of bangs, explosions, or crashes. Like 🔥 Fire and 💯 Hundred Points, commonly used to represent something is excellent or exciting in some way.
 Apple implements a version of 💥 Collision in its 🧨 Firecracker and 📸 Camera With Flash.


 Collision was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Collision Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:15,gallery_id:2,emoji:"💫",name:"Dizzy",meaning:"A cartoon-styled representation of dizziness. Generally depicted as one or more yellow stars swirling in a yellow or blue circle. 
Resembles squeans, stylized stars and circles over the heads of characters in comics and animation to show they are dizzy, disoriented, intoxicated, or sick.
 Commonly used for emphasis and flair or to indicate various positive sentiments. Like 🌠 Shooting Star, sometimes used as a visual reference to NBC’s More You Know public service announcement, popular in the 1990s and featuring a shooting star logo.
Not to be confused with ⭐ Star, 🌟 Glowing Star, and ✨ Sparkles, though their applications may overlap.
 Facebook’s design features two stars spinning along two intersecting purple circles, though it previously only featured one yellow ring. Samsung’s design previously displayed several yellow circles and stars.


Dizzy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Dizzy Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:16,gallery_id:2,emoji:"💦",name:"Sweat Droplets",meaning:"Three, light blue droplets, as sweat beads, splashing down to the right. Resembles plewds, stylized sweat droplets used in comics and animation to show characters working hard or feeling stressed. 
 May be used to represent various types of liquids, including sexual fluids. May also be used to represent various liquid-based slang expressions (e.g., drip, 'exceptional style, swagger').
 
 
 Not to be confused with 💧 Droplet, though their applications may overlap.

 Google, Microsoft, and Samsung's design previously featured two, upwardly directed droplets.
 
 
 Sweat Droplets was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Splashing Sweat Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:17,gallery_id:2,emoji:"💨",name:"Dashing Away",meaning:"A cartoon-styled gust of air. Depicted as a small, gray cloud with motion lines, rushing to the left. 

 Resembles briffits, a stylized cloud of dust used in comics and animation to indicate someone or something has dashed away (e.g., leaving someone in the dust). 

 May be used to represent speed, smoking, and various types of wind, blown or broken. May precede other emoji, such as 🏃Runner or 🚗 Automobile, to indicate something is fast or fleeing: 🏃💨, 🚗💨.

  Not to be confused 🌬️ Wind Face, though their applications may overlap.

 Dashing Away was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Dash Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:18,gallery_id:2,emoji:"🐵",name:"Monkey Face",meaning:"A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a monkey, looking straight ahead. Depicted as a brown-haired monkey with a tan or pinkish face, round ears, nostrils, and open-mouthed smile. 
 As with the full-bodied 🐒 Monkey, often used with a playful tone or for metaphorical senses of monkey. 

 One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Available as an Apple Animoji. 

Vendors implement the same or similar monkey face in their Three Wise Monkeys emojis: 🙈 See-No-Evil Monkey, 🙉 Hear-No-Evil Monkey, and 🙊 Speak-No-Evil Monkey.

Facebook’s monkey previously resembled 🐻 Bear Face.

This emoji is considered racist in some contexts, especially when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people.

 Monkey Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:19,gallery_id:2,emoji:"🐒",name:"Monkey",meaning:"A monkey, a small primate with long limbs and tail for climbing trees. Generally depicted as a cartoon-styled, brown monkey with a cheeky facial expression, shown in full profile facing left, sitting on its hind legs with a long, curled tail and round ears. 
 As with 🐵 Monkey Face, often used with a playful tone or for metaphorical senses of monkey. 
 One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. 
 WhatsApp’s monkey is facing right, Facebook’s has shaggy hair. 
 This emoji is considered racist in some contexts, especially when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people. 
 Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:21,gallery_id:3,emoji:"🍇",name:"Grapes",meaning:"A grape bunch, as cut from the vine and used to make wine. Depicted as red (purple-colored) grapes. 

 Grapes was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:22,gallery_id:3,emoji:"🍈",name:"Melon",meaning:"A melon fruit in a light greenish-brown rind. Depicted as a cantaloupe by most platforms, but can resemble a honeydew at a distance. 

 Melon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:23,gallery_id:3,emoji:"🍉",name:"Watermelon",meaning:"A slice of watermelon, showing its rich pink flesh, black seeds, and green rind. 

\ Watermelon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:24,gallery_id:3,emoji:"🍊",name:"Tangerine",meaning:"An orange-colored citrus fruit with a green leaf or leaves and stem. Officially depicting a tangerine, a type of mandarin (mikan in Japan). Often used as a garden-variety orange. Either way, a good source of vitamin C. 

 Tangerine was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:25,gallery_id:3,emoji:"🍋",name:"Lemon",meaning:"The sour, yellow-colored citrus fruit of the lemon, usually with a stem and green leaf or leaves. 
 Spiked in use thanks to Beyoncé’s 2016 album, Lemonade.

 Lemon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:26,gallery_id:3,emoji:"🍌",name:"Banana",meaning:"A ripe banana, peeled and ready to eat on major platforms. Great snack for a child or monkey. 

 Banana was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:27,gallery_id:3,emoji:"🍍",name:"Pineapple",meaning:"The tropical fruit of a pineapple, shown in spiky, golden-brown skin and with a pointed, green crown. Positioned upright or at a 45° angle. 

 Pineapple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:28,gallery_id:3,emoji:"🍎",name:"Red Apple",meaning:"A classic red apple, shown with a stem and single, green leaf on major platforms. Commonly associated with doctors, teachers, and New York. 

 Red Apple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:29,gallery_id:3,emoji:"🍏",name:"Green Apple",meaning:"A common green apple, tarter counterpart to the Red Apple. Displayed with a stem and single, green leaf on major platforms.

 Green Apple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:31,gallery_id:4,emoji:"🕴️",name:"Person in Suit Levitating",meaning:"A person wearing a suit, hovering above the ground with a shadow displayed beneath them. Generally shown wearing a fedora or similar style of hat. 
 This character was originally introduced into the Webdings font as an “exclamation mark in the style of the rude boy logo found on records by The Specials". This levitating man was known as Walt Jabsco. 
 Person in Suit Levitating was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name \“Man in Business Suit Levitating\” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:32,gallery_id:4,emoji:"🧗",name:"Person Climbing",meaning:"A rock climber, shown climbing up a rock formation. Some platforms show the climber with a helmet and/or rope. The Emojipedia Sample image was created with assistance from World Champion Rock Climber Sasha DiGiulian. Variations exist for 🧗‍♀️ Woman Climbing and 🧗‍♂️ Man Climbing. Person Climbing was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:33,gallery_id:4,emoji:"🧗‍♂️",name:"Man Climbing",meaning:"A male rock climber, shown climbing up a rock formation. Some platforms show the climber with a helmet, and/or rope. Variations exist for 🧗‍♀️ Woman Climbing and 🧗 Person Climbing.
  The Man Climbing emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧗 Person Climbing, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂️ Male Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. 

 Man Climbing was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:34,gallery_id:4,emoji:"🧗‍♀️",name:"Woman Climbing",meaning:"A female rock climber, shown climbing up a rock formation. Some platforms show the climber with a helmet, and/or rope. Variations exist for 🧗‍♂️ Man Climbing and 🧗 Person Climbing. The Woman Climbing emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧗 Person Climbing, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀️ Female Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. 

 Woman Climbing was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:35,gallery_id:4,emoji:"🤺",name:"Person Fencing",meaning:"A person shown in the sport of fencing, with a Rapier-style sword, mask, and protective clothing. 

 Person Fencing was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Fencer” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:36,gallery_id:4,emoji:"🏇",name:"Horse Racing",meaning:"A jockey riding a horse in a horse race. Shown riding to the left of screen on all major platforms. Emoji modifiers change the skin tone of the jockey on some platforms, which can be difficult to discern at small sizes. 

 Horse Racing was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:37,gallery_id:4,emoji:"⛷️",name:"Skier",meaning:"A person downhill-skiiing. Displayed with poles and skis, generally wearing a mask. 

 Platforms vary in display of scarf, helmet, and color of clothing. No gendered options are provided for this emoji. Skin tones support is not recommended for this emoji, but this is supported by some platforms. 

 Skier was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:38,gallery_id:4,emoji:"🏂",name:"Snowboarder",meaning:"A person snowboarding downhill at a ski resort. Wearing clothing designed for cold climates. Snowboarder was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:39,gallery_id:4,emoji:"🏌️",name:"Person Golfing",meaning:"A person swinging a golf club, attempting to hit a golf ball toward the flag on the green. Person Golfing was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Golfer” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:41,gallery_id:5,emoji:"🚣",name:"Person Rowing Boat",meaning:"A small rowboat suitable for a small number of people. Couples or families sometimes hire these as an activity on calm waters. 

 Person Rowing Boat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Rowboat” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:42,gallery_id:5,emoji:"🗾",name:"Map of Japan",meaning:"Shows a map of the country of Japan, which is the only country to have its own emoji map. Other countries can be found on the various globe emojis, or the world map emoji. 

 Map of Japan was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Silhouette of Japan” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:43,gallery_id:5,emoji:"🏔️",name:"Snow-Capped Mountain",meaning:"A mountain with snow resting at higher altitudes. Similar in appearance to the Mount Fuji emoji. 

 Snow-Capped Mountain was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Snow Capped Mountain” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:44,gallery_id:5,emoji:"⛰️",name:"Mountain",meaning:"A mountain shown with two peaks and blue sky. Similar to the snow capped mountain emoji. 

 Mountain was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:45,gallery_id:5,emoji:"🌋",name:"Volcano",meaning:"A volcano, erupting with smoke and lava. Volcano was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:46,gallery_id:5,emoji:"🗻",name:"Mount Fuji",meaning:"Mount Fuji (called Fuji-san in Japan) is the largest mountain in Japan. Often seen with snow on the peak in colder months of the year. 

  It is considered lucky in Japan to dream of Mt Fuji in the first dream of the new year. 

 Mount Fuji was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:47,gallery_id:5,emoji:"🏕️",name:"Camping",meaning:"A campsite featuring a tent and a tree, and perhaps a campfire. Similar to the tent emoji. 

 Camping was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:48,gallery_id:5,emoji:"🏖️",name:"Beach with Umbrella",meaning:"A beach showing sand, and an umbrella for protection from the sun. 

 Beach with Umbrella was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:49,gallery_id:5,emoji:"🏜️",name:"Desert",meaning:"Desert was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:50,gallery_id:6,emoji:"💌",name:"Love Letter",meaning:"The back of an envelope, generally shown in white and sealed with a red heart. Represents a love letter or note, valentine, or affectionate greeting card. Commonly used to convey various feelings or messages of love and happiness. Microsoft’s envelope is open, Facebook’s is pink. 

 Love Letter was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:51,gallery_id:6,emoji:"🕳️",name:"Hole",meaning:"A round, black, cartoon-styled hole, as a manhole or a hole (cup) in golf. May be used to represent various types of literal or figurative holes, e.g., black holes, rabbit holes. 

 Hole was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:52,gallery_id:6,emoji:"💣",name:"Bomb",meaning:"A cartoon-styled bomb, depicted as a black ball with a burning fuse. Commonly used for various figurative bombs or explosions, e.g., slang bomb, a “home run” in baseball or softball; "excellent" or "attractive." Sometimes applied in contexts of war, weapons, or violence. Earlier designs from SoftBank and au by KDDI animated the bomb as exploding. 

 Bomb was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:53,gallery_id:6,emoji:"🛀",name:"Person Taking Bath",meaning:"A gender-unspecified person taking a soothing bath in a white tub with a shower head. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, cleaning, and bathrooms more generally. May also represent relaxation and self-care. The appearance of the person, depicted in default yellow, varies. Apple's person is wearing a green shower cap, WhatsApp's a green washcloth. Google’s person appears to be playing in a bubble bath, with soapsuds atop their ahead. Other major vendors show the head of the bather with short, brown or blonde hair. Skin tone modifiers are available on supported platforms. 

  Vendors implement the same or a similar tub and shower head as for their 🛁 Bathtub, but with a person taking/having a bath. 


 Person Taking Bath was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Bath” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:54,gallery_id:6,emoji:"⏰",name:" Alarm Clock",meaning:"A gender-unspecified person taking a soothing bath in a white tub with a shower head. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, cleaning, and bathrooms more generally. May also represent relaxation and self-care. 
 The appearance of the person, depicted in default yellow, varies. Apple's person is wearing a green shower cap, WhatsApp's a green washcloth. Google’s person appears to be playing in a bubble bath, with soapsuds atop their ahead. Other major vendors show the head of the bather with short, brown or blonde hair. Skin tone modifiers are available on supported platforms. 

 Vendors implement the same or a similar tub and shower head as for their 🛁 Bathtub, but with a person taking/having a bath. 

 Person Taking Bath was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Bath” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:55,gallery_id:6,emoji:"🛌",name:"Person in Bed",meaning:"A bed with a gender-unspecified person sleeping in it, as at a house, hotel, hostel, or other sleeping accommodation. Used especially for various content concerning sleeping as well as beds, furniture, housing, relaxing, and other bedroom activities. Shown with a headboard at the left and footboard with a person under the covers, head on the pillow. Most platforms suggest a wooden frame and feature blue or red sheets. The appearance of the person varies. Apple and Facebook's designs show only the hair of the sleeper, Apple's black and Facebook's brown and tousled. Other major vendors show the head of the sleeper in default yellow with short, brown or blonde hair. Skin tone support is not recommended for this emoji, though it is supported on some platforms. Vendors implement the same style of bed as for their 🛏️ Bed, but with a sleeper in it. 

 Person in Bed was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Sleeping Accommodation” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:56,gallery_id:6,emoji:"🔪",name:"Kitchen Knife",meaning:"A knife with a long steel blade, as a chef uses to slice meat or vegetables. Depicted with a black or brown handle and positioned at a 45° angle, often with its point at the lower right. May be used for content concerning cooking and food preparation, but often represents various senses of cutting and stabbing. Its Unicode name, Hocho, means “kitchen knife” in Japanese and refers to a variety of knives used in Japan. Not to be confused with 🗡️ Dagger or ⚔️ Crossed Swords. 

 Kitchen Knife was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Hocho” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:57,gallery_id:6,emoji:"🏺",name:"Amphora",meaning:"A tall, ceramic jar with two handles and a narrow neck and foot. Represents an amphora, as used by ancient Greeks and Romans to hold water and wine. Generally depicted as brownish-red earthenware ornamented with black and a Greek meander pattern.  May represent containers like vases, pottery, museums, history, and antiquity. May also be used in relation to the zodiac sign of Aquarius, the Water-Bearer.  Not to be confused with ⚱️ Funeral Urn. Amphora was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:58,gallery_id:6,emoji:"🗺️",name:"World Map",meaning:"A rectangular map of the world. Generally depicted as a paper map creased at its folds, Earth’s surface shown in green on blue ocean. Commonly represent maps, travel, exploration, and geography. May also represent various content concerning the world as a whole, e.g., global or international issues. Microsoft and Samsung’s design previously depicted outlines of the continents. 

 World Map was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:60,gallery_id:7,emoji:"💘",name:"Heart with Arrow",meaning:"A heart emoji with an arrow through the center, like the arrow that cupid shoots for love. 

 Heart with Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:61,gallery_id:7,emoji:"💝",name:"Heart with Ribbon",meaning:"A heart-shaped box, tied with a ribbon. May be a gift box, box of chocolates, or a jewellery box. 

 Heart with Ribbon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:62,gallery_id:7,emoji:"💖",name:"Sparkling Heart",meaning:"A pink love heart with stars around it, making it look like it is sparkling or shimmering. Sparkling Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:63,gallery_id:7,emoji:"💗",name:"Growing Heart",meaning:"A pink heart, inside a slightly larger pink heart, inside a larger-again pink heart. Intended to give the impression of a heart increasing in size. 

 Growing Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:64,gallery_id:7,emoji:"💓",name:"Beating Heart",meaning:"A heart with vibration / movement lines above it, indicating it is a beating heart. Displayed in pink or red on most platforms, this emoji is intended to be used as a beating heart representing either life, or love. 

 Beating Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:65,gallery_id:7,emoji:"💞",name:"Revolving Hearts",meaning:"Hearts revolving around one or more other hearts. This emoji was originally animated on a number of Japanese devices. Apple’s artwork for this emoji shows two hearts switching places, with a circular line simulating the action this would make. Google’s artwork previously displayed five hearts in a circle-like shape. Revolving Hearts was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:66,gallery_id:7,emoji:"💕",name:"Two Hearts",meaning:"Two pink love hearts. One larger than the other. Can be used to display that “love is in the air”. 

 On Snapchat, this emoji next to a contact denotes that you have been #1 BFs with each other for two consecutive months. A bug in October 2019 has a yellow heart emoji showing instead of 💕 for some Snapchat users.

 Two Hearts was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:67,gallery_id:7,emoji:"💟",name:"Heart Decoration",meaning:"A decorative heart that displays on Apple devices as a white heart-shaped cutout in a pink or purple roundrect. 

Heart Decoration was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:68,gallery_id:7,emoji:"❣️",name:"Heart Exclamation",meaning:"A decorative exclamation mark, where a heart forms the top part of the symbol, and a circle the lower part. Similar to the way to the man in business suit levitating also creates a similar shape. 

 Heart Exclamation was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Heavy Heart Exclamation Mark Ornament” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:70,gallery_id:8,emoji:"🇺🇸",name:"The United State",meaning:"The flag for the United States of America (USA), which may show as the letters US on some platforms. The Flag: United States emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇺 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter U and 🇸 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter S. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.  Flag: United States was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:71,gallery_id:8,emoji:"🏁",name:"Chequered Flag",meaning:"A flag with black and white squares shown in a checkerboard pattern, used to signal the start or end of a motor car race.  Chequered Flag was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:72,gallery_id:8,emoji:"🇺🇿",name:"Uzbekistan",meaning:"The flag for Uzbekistan, which may show as the letters UZ on some platforms. The Flag: Uzbekistan emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇺 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter U and 🇿 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter Z. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. Flag: Uzbekistan was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:73,gallery_id:8,emoji:"🚩",name:"Triangular Flag",meaning:"A triangular red flag on a post. Most commonly associated with golf, as shown in the flag in hole emoji. Triangular Flag was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Triangular Flag on Post” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:74,gallery_id:8,emoji:"🎌",name:"Crossed Flags",meaning:"Two Japanese Flags, crossed at the base. Except on some Samsung devices, which have previously displayed two South Korean flags.  Crossed Flags was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:75,gallery_id:8,emoji:"🏴",name:"Black Flag",meaning:"Black Flag was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Waving Black Flag” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:76,gallery_id:8,emoji:"🏳️",name:"White Flag",meaning:"A white flag, shown waving on a post. Traditionally used as a sign of surrender, the meaning of this flag as an emoji is less defined. 

 White Flag was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Waving White Flag” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:77,gallery_id:8,emoji:"🇦🇪",name:"United Arab Emirates",meaning:"The flag for United Arab Emirates, which may show as the letters AE on some platforms. The Flag: United Arab Emirates emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇦 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter A and 🇪 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter E. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. 

 Flag: United Arab Emirates was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."},{image:'/images/emoji/',id:78,gallery_id:8,emoji:"🇰🇷",name:"South Korea",meaning:"The flag for South Korea, which may show as the letters KR on some platforms.  The Flag: South Korea emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇰 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter K and 🇷 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter R. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. 

 Flag: South Korea was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015"}];export default emojibook;

const emojibook = [
    {  
        image:'/images/emoji/',
      id: 1,
      gallery_id:1,
      emoji: "😀",
      name: "Grinning Face",
      meaning:
        "A yellow face with simple, open eyes and a broad, open smile, showing upper teeth and tongue on some platforms.\n Often conveys general pleasure and good cheer or humor.\n Not to be confused with 😃 Grinning Face With Big Eyes or 😄 Grinning Face With Smiling Eyes, which have the same smiles but more expressive eye shapes. \n\n This emoji has a cat variant, 😺 Grinning Cat Face."
    },
    {  
        image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 2,
        gallery_id:1,
        emoji: "😃",
        name: "Grinning Face with Big ",
        meaning:
            "A yellow face with smiling eyes and a broad, open smile, showing upper teeth and tongue on some platforms. Often conveys general happiness and good-natured amusement.\n\n Similar to 😀 Grinning Face but with taller, more excited eyes. "     
     },
     {  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 3,
        gallery_id:1,
        emoji: "😄",
        name: "Grinning Face with Smiling ",
        meaning:
            "A yellow face with smiling eyes and a broad, open smile, showing upper teeth and tongue on some platforms. Often conveys general happiness and good-natured amusement.\n\nSimilar to 😀 Grinning Face and 😃 Grinning Face With Big Eyes, but with warmer, less excited eyes.\n\nThis emoji has a cat variant, 😸 Grinning Cat Face With Smiling Eyes."     
     },
     {  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 4,
        gallery_id:1,
        emoji: "😁",
        name: "Beaming Face with Smiling ",
        meaning:
            "A yellow face with smiling eyes and full-toothed grin, as if saying Cheese! for the camera. Teeth may be smoothed-over or crosshatched. Often expresses a radiant, gratified happiness. Tone varies, including warm, silly, amused, or proud. \n\nPrior to 2017, Apple's design resembled its 😬 Grimacing Face."     
     },
     {  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 5,
        gallery_id:1,
        emoji: "😆",
        name: "Grinning Squinting Face",
        meaning:
            "A yellow face with a broad, open smile and scrunched, X-shaped eyes. Often conveys excitement or hearty laughter.\n Similar to 😀 Grinning Face but with eyes that might say Squee! or Awesome! An emoji form of the >< or xD emoticons. \n\nGrinning Squinting Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Smiling Face with Open Mouth and Tightly-Closed Eyes” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },
     {  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 6,
        gallery_id:1,
        emoji: "😅",
        name: "Grinning Face with Sweat",
        meaning:
            "Has the same grin and eyes as 😄 Grinning Face With Smiling Eyes but with a single, blue bead of sweat, usually over its left eye. Intended to depict nerves or discomfort but commonly used to express a close call, as if saying Whew! and wiping sweat from the forehead. \n\n\nGrinning Face with Sweat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Smiling Face with Open Mouth and Cold Sweat” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },
     {  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 7,
        gallery_id:1,
        emoji: "🤣",
        name: "Rolling on the Floor Laughing",
        meaning:
            "A yellow face with a big grin and scrunched, X-shaped eyes, tilted on its side as if rolling on the floor laughing (the internet acronym ROFL). Sheds two tears and tilts right on most platforms. Often conveys hysterical laughter more intense than 😂 Face With Tears of Joy.\n Microsoft's design previously featured a smiley with hands and feet. \n\n Rolling on the Floor Laughing was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016."     
     },
     {  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 8,
        gallery_id:1,
        emoji: "😂",
        name: "Face with Tears of Joy",
        meaning:
            "A yellow face with a big grin, uplifted eyebrows, and smiling eyes, each shedding a tear from laughing so hard. Widely used to show something is funny or pleasing. Named the Oxford Dictionaries 2015 Word of the Year, and the most used emoji on all platforms from 2011-2021.\n\n See also: 🤣 Rolling on the Floor Laughing which expresses more intense laughter; or cat variant: 😹 Cat Face With Tears of Joy.\n\n\n Face with Tears of Joy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },
     {  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 9,
        gallery_id:1,
        emoji: "🙂",
        name: "Slightly Smiling Face",
        meaning:
            "A yellow face with simple, open eyes and a thin, closed smile. Conveys a wide range of positive, happy, and friendly sentiments. Its tone can also be patronizing, passive-aggressive, or ironic, as if saying This is fine when it’s really not. \n\n\n Slightly Smiling Face was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },
    {  
        image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 11,
        gallery_id:2,
        emoji: "🙈",
        name: "See-No-Evil Monkey",
        meaning:
            "The see no evil monkey, called Mizaru (Japanese for “see not”), one of the Three Wise Monkeys. Depicted as the brown 🐵 Monkey Face with hands covering its eyes.\n The Three Wise Monkeys represent the proverb see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil, frequently interpreted as a call for discretion or willful ignorance.\n Often used as a playful way to convey a laughing, disbelieving, cringing I can’t believe what I’m seeing! or I can’t bear to look! \n See also 🙉 Hear-No-Evil Monkey and 🙊 Speak-No-Evil Monkey.\n\nThis emoji is considered racist in some contexts, especially when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people.\n\n\n See-No-Evil Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },
     {  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 12,
        gallery_id:2,
        emoji: "🙉",
        name: "Hear-No-Evil Monkey",
        meaning:
            "The hear no evil monkey, called Kikazaru (Japanese for “hear not”), one of the Three Wise Monkeys. Depicted as the brown 🐵 Monkey Face with hands covering its ears.\n The Three Wise Monkeys represent the proverb see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil, frequently interpreted as a call for discretion or willful ignorance. \n Often used as a playful way to convey I can’t believe what I’m hearing! or, more generally, to express astonishment or disbelief. \n\n See also 🙈 See-No-Evil Monkey and 🙊 Speak-No-Evil Monkey.\n  This emoji is considered racist in some contexts, especially when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people.\n\n\n Hear-No-Evil Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },
     {  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 13,

May be used to similar effect as 🤭 Face With Hand Over Mouth or 🤐 Zipper Mouth.\n See also 🙈 See-No-Evil Monkey and 🙉 Hear-No-Evil Monkey.\n\nThis emoji is considered racist in some contexts, especially when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people.\n\n\n Speak-No-Evil Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },
     {  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 14,
        gallery_id:2,
        emoji: "💥",
        name: "Collision",
        meaning:
            "A cartoon-styled representation of a collision. Depicted as a star-like, orange-and-yellow fiery burst, generally with one point extending to the bottom right, as if from the source of the collision.\nMay be used to represent various types of bangs, explosions, or crashes. Like 🔥 Fire and 💯 Hundred Points, commonly used to represent something is excellent or exciting in some way.\n Apple implements a version of 💥 Collision in its 🧨 Firecracker and 📸 Camera With Flash.\n\n\n Collision was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Collision Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },{  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 15,
        gallery_id:2,
        emoji: "💫",
        name: "Dizzy",
        meaning:
            "A cartoon-styled representation of dizziness. Generally depicted as one or more yellow stars swirling in a yellow or blue circle. \nResembles squeans, stylized stars and circles over the heads of characters in comics and animation to show they are dizzy, disoriented, intoxicated, or sick.\n Commonly used for emphasis and flair or to indicate various positive sentiments. Like 🌠 Shooting Star, sometimes used as a visual reference to NBC’s More You Know public service announcement, popular in the 1990s and featuring a shooting star logo.\nNot to be confused with ⭐ Star, 🌟 Glowing Star, and ✨ Sparkles, though their applications may overlap.\n Facebook’s design features two stars spinning along two intersecting purple circles, though it previously only featured one yellow ring. Samsung’s design previously displayed several yellow circles and stars.\n\n\nDizzy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Dizzy Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },{  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 16,
        gallery_id:2,
        emoji: "💦",
        name: "Sweat Droplets",
        meaning:
            "Three, light blue droplets, as sweat beads, splashing down to the right. Resembles plewds, stylized sweat droplets used in comics and animation to show characters working hard or feeling stressed. \n May be used to represent various types of liquids, including sexual fluids. May also be used to represent various liquid-based slang expressions (e.g., drip, 'exceptional style, swagger').\n \n \n Not to be confused with 💧 Droplet, though their applications may overlap.\n\n Google, Microsoft, and Samsung's design previously featured two, upwardly directed droplets.\n \n \n Sweat Droplets was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Splashing Sweat Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },{  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 17,
        gallery_id:2,
        emoji: "💨",
        name: "Dashing Away",
        meaning:
            "A cartoon-styled gust of air. Depicted as a small, gray cloud with motion lines, rushing to the left. \n\n Resembles briffits, a stylized cloud of dust used in comics and animation to indicate someone or something has dashed away (e.g., leaving someone in the dust). \n\n May be used to represent speed, smoking, and various types of wind, blown or broken. May precede other emoji, such as 🏃Runner or 🚗 Automobile, to indicate something is fast or fleeing: 🏃💨, 🚗💨.\n\n  Not to be confused 🌬️ Wind Face, though their applications may overlap.\n\n Dashing Away was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Dash Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."

         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 18,
        gallery_id:2,
        emoji: "🐵",

Depicted as a brown-haired monkey with a tan or pinkish face, round ears, nostrils, and open-mouthed smile. \n As with the full-bodied 🐒 Monkey, often used with a playful tone or for metaphorical senses of monkey. \n\n One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. Available as an Apple Animoji. \n\nVendors implement the same or similar monkey face in their Three Wise Monkeys emojis: 🙈 See-No-Evil Monkey, 🙉 Hear-No-Evil Monkey, and 🙊 Speak-No-Evil Monkey.\n\nFacebook’s monkey previously resembled 🐻 Bear Face.\n\nThis emoji is considered racist in some contexts, especially when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people.\n\n Monkey Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },{  
         image:'/images/emoji/',

Generally depicted as a cartoon-styled, brown monkey with a cheeky facial expression, shown in full profile facing left, sitting on its hind legs with a long, curled tail and round ears. \n As with 🐵 Monkey Face, often used with a playful tone or for metaphorical senses of monkey. \n One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac. \n WhatsApp’s monkey is facing right, Facebook’s has shaggy hair. \n This emoji is considered racist in some contexts, especially when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people. \n Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."

         image:'/images/emoji/',

         image:'/images/emoji/',

        emoji: "🍉",

         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 24,
        gallery_id:3,
        emoji: "🍊",
        name: "Tangerine",
        meaning:
            "An orange-colored citrus fruit with a green leaf or leaves and stem. Officially depicting a tangerine, a type of mandarin (mikan in Japan). Often used as a garden-variety orange. Either way, a good source of vitamin C. \n\n Tangerine was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },{  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 25,

     },{  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 26,
        gallery_id:3,
        emoji: "🍌",
        name: "Banana",
        meaning:
            "A ripe banana, peeled and ready to eat on major platforms. Great snack for a child or monkey. \n\n Banana was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },{  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 27,
        gallery_id:3,
        emoji: "🍍",
        name: "Pineapple",
        meaning:
            "The tropical fruit of a pineapple, shown in spiky, golden-brown skin and with a pointed, green crown. Positioned upright or at a 45° angle. \n\n Pineapple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },{  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 28,
        gallery_id:3,
        emoji: "🍎",
        name: "Red Apple",
        meaning:
            "A classic red apple, shown with a stem and single, green leaf on major platforms. Commonly associated with doctors, teachers, and New York. \n\n Red Apple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."     
     },{  
         image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 29,
        gallery_id:3,
        emoji: "🍏",
        name: "Green Apple",
        meaning:
            "A common green apple, tarter counterpart to the Red Apple. Displayed with a stem and single, green leaf on major platforms.\n\n Green Apple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015."

This levitating man was known as Walt Jabsco. \n Person in Suit Levitating was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name \“Man in Business Suit Levitating\” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015." 
    },
    {  
        image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 32,
        gallery_id:4,
        emoji: "🧗",
        name: "Person Climbing",
        meaning:
            "A rock climber, shown climbing up a rock formation. Some platforms show the climber with a helmet and/or rope. Person Climbing was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017."

    {  
        image:'/images/emoji/',

Variations exist for 🧗‍♀️ Woman Climbing and 🧗 Person Climbing.\n  The Man Climbing emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧗 Person Climbing, ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂️ Male Sign. These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. \n\n Man Climbing was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017."

These display as a single emoji on supported platforms. \n\n Woman Climbing was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017." 
    },
    {  
        image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 35,
        gallery_id:4,
        emoji: "🤺",
        name: "Person Fencing",
        meaning:

    },
    {  
        image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 36,
        gallery_id:4,
        emoji: "🏇",
        name: "Horse Racing",
        meaning:
            "A jockey riding a horse in a horse race. Shown riding to the left of screen on all major platforms. Emoji modifiers change the skin tone of the jockey on some platforms, which can be difficult to discern at small sizes. \n\n Horse Racing was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015." 
    },
    {  
        image:'/images/emoji/',
        id: 37,
        gallery_id:4,
        emoji: "⛷️",
